content: Can I make a suggestion that would simplify this a bit? You could have the maps completely surrounded by water on the edges, to eliminate the need for bounds checking during the recursive search. You could furthermore guarantee, without changing the adjacency rules, that every island is completely surrounded by water even on the diagonals, so that the problem could actually be solved using either adjacency condition, 4 or 8. The latter is easier to iterate over.
I would solve it with a bit optimization: don't check already calculated cells. But, task is good!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle about basic graph searches

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle can be solved in about 7 minutes. The goal is clear, and the puzzle is quite fun.
This is a straightforward problem and solvable in about 8 minutes. I like that the grid is [[n]] by [[n]] so that you don't have to think about which dimension applies to which constraint.

Input
* Please change "Line1" to "Line 1".

* Please change "N" to "[[n]]".

* Please change "Line2 ~ n + 1" to "Next [[n]] lines".

* Please change "2D of islands containing only {{1}} and {{0}}" to "Each line shows one row of the grid, which contains [[n]] characters of {{1}} and {{0}}, separated by a space".

Constraints
* Please change "<" to "≤" as there are cases where [[n]] = 20.

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution, because it's a cool puzzle, it's readable and passable in approx. 7-8 minutes

Hello, that's not a puzzle... To finish this problem you only have 15min and to validate this clash of code and you must have completed it in less than 5min.

Does it always match or is it a typo error ?

Sorry for my mistake, yes I understood the difference. Knowledge of this type of solution is basic for algorithmic competitors. So, if smb needs more than 15 minutes - it would be a good hint where to practise and learn

You've validated this contribution in a clash of code, so the aim is for anyone to be able to produce their solution in under 15 minutes. If you can't do it yourself in under 5 minutes, I wouldn't recommend validating the contribution: most people won't be able to solve the clash in time.

I invite you to reconsider your validation in this case.
Can I share my solution in comments? It's kinda simple even if man would not know about dfs he would be able to make up algorithm from scratch
All is possible with some time... The question is "is possible to make up algorithm from scratch under 15min for every body ?"

I think yes, because main idea is not hard and only about theese 3 steps:
Recursively explore all connected land cells.
Convert visited land cells to water (0) to avoid revisiting.
Track the largest island during the exploration.
In my experience, the principle of double loops in an table to evaluate all cases is not a concept that every beginner masters. I'm still on the fence about it, but if you think it is, it must be.

That's an interesting simplification. It still took me 8 minutes to solve it that way, but that was due to a couple of misdirections, like accidentally including corners instead of just the 4 adjacent.
